awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Deep Propagating Gravity Wave (DEEPWAVE)
awd_abstract_narration:
DEEP propagating gravity WAVE (DEEPWAVE) is an interdisciplinary project addressing the  propagation and effects of gravity waves (GW) extending from their generation in the troposphere to their breakdown in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT). The project is designed by experts on the MLT and the lower atmosphere. These research communities have not worked closely together before, but a coupled approach is required to address these dynamics in a comprehensive and consistent manner. GWs strongly influence the dynamics and climate throughout the atmosphere. DEEPWAVE will provide a more complete understanding of GW generation, propagation, breakdown, and energy and momentum transport in the presence of large topography, cyclones, and strong wind shears than has been possible previously.
	At the core of the project is a 6-week deployment of the NSF Gulfstream V (GV) research aircraft to Christchurch in June and July 2014. The GV flights will take place over mountain wave locations over and downwind of New Zealand, Tasmania, and islands in the Southern Ocean as well as the southern circumpolar jet that is an additional strong GW source. Recent satellite remote sensing has identified this region as a primary global "hotspot" of GWs reaching high altitudes.  Using the GV in situ instruments, dropsondes, and three new airborne remote sensing instruments, nearly the full vertical propagation path of GWs can be observed.
 	The GV will fly at altitudes from 9-13 km with in situ instruments observing the structure and fluxes of GWs up to ~18 km. On the GV, high-power Rayleigh and Na resonance lidars and an advanced mesospheric temperature mapper (AMTM) will map out GW structures from ~15 to 100 km. These state-of-the-art measurements will be supplemented by ground-based balloon and remote sensing instruments. 
	This 4-year research program includes DEEPWAVE measurements in 2014, and extensive analysis efforts and associated modeling to quantify the observed dynamics thereafter. All DEEPWAVE data will be made available in a timely fashion. In addition to the investigators supported by this collaborative award, participants supported by NRL as well as international collaborators from New Zealand, Australia, Canada, Germany and the UK will be closely involved in the DEEPWAVE project.

DEEPWAVE Project Outcomes (Yale Group)

 

Internal gravity waves (GW) frequently occur in the earth’s atmosphere, often reaching the high altitudes of the stratosphere and mesosphere. Since the 1970s, it has been realized that these waves have a significant and cumulative impact on weather and climate but it has proven difficult to represent their effect in numerical models. This difficulty arises from 1) the multiple different GW sources, 2) the sensitivity of GWs to their environment causing highly transient behavior, 3) the wide range of GW scales. Until recently, GW parametrizations in climate models have been “tuned” for optimum impact but this approach has given poor overall results. The objective of DEEPWAVE was observe GW more accurately and completely and develop a better physical understanding and an improved prediction scheme.  In pursuit of this goal, the DEEPWAVE field project took place in New Zealand in June/July 2014, followed by four years of data analysis, numerical simulation and advanced theoretical work.  Many peer-reviewed research papers were published by the PIs, including eleven by the Yale group reported here.

For brevity, we mention the three most surprising and important of the Yale DEEPWAVE findings.

  1. We challenged the conventional mono-chromatic GW parametrization by showing the breadth of the GW spectrum. We showed that aircraft data systems, because they can observe many different variables (i.e. u,v,w,p,T), can determine the relative importance of different GW scales (i.e. from 10 to 400km). Other observing systems (e.g. balloons, lidar, satellite) are prone to scale biases. We proposed a new scheme in which the terrain  “volume mode” long waves and the terrain “roughness mode” short waves are treated separately.

  2. We showed that the dominant control on deep wave propagation into the mesosphere is the speed of the winds in the low stratosphere near z=16km.  We named this layer the “valve layer”. With higher wind speeds there, the “valve” is open and waves can reach the mesosphere. With slower wind speeds at z=16km, wave breaking occurs there and little wave energy reaches the mesosphere.

  3. We developed a new “Matrix Theory” for mountain wave generation by complex terrain. The positive-definite drag matrix (computed in Fourier Space) is multiplied by the low level wind vector to determine the total momentum flux vector. The application of this method to New Zealand gave surprisingly good results, as shown in Smith and Kruse 2018 (Figure 8).
